abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Heterozygous missense variants in the <jats:italic>WD repeat domain 11</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>WDR11</jats:italic>) gene are associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in humans. In contrast, knockout of both alleles of <jats:italic>Wdr11</jats:italic> in mice results in a more severe phenotype with growth and developmental delay, features of holoprosencephaly, heart defects and reproductive disorders. Similar developmental defects known to be associated with aberrant hedgehog signaling and ciliogenesis have been found in zebrafish after <jats:italic>Wdr11</jats:italic> knockdown. We here report biallelic loss-of-function variants in the <jats:italic>WDR11</jats:italic> gene in six patients from three independent families with intellectual disability, microcephaly and short stature. The findings suggest that biallelic <jats:italic>WDR11</jats:italic> variants in humans result in an overlapping but milder phenotype compared to <jats:italic>Wdr11</jats:italic>-deficient animals. However, the observed human phenotype differs significantly from dominantly inherited variants leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, suggesting that recessive <jats:italic>WDR11</jats:italic> variants result in a clinically distinct entity.</jats:p>
